title: Former Trump Campaign Manager Stonewalls House Panel
text:
WASHINGTON—Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski stonewalled lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee about his conversations with President Trump for nearly six hours on Tuesday, after the White House sought to impose limits on the scope of his testimony.

Mr. Lewandowski affirmed the accuracy of elements of former special counsel Robert Mueller’s report on Russian interference in the 2016 election and any White House obstruction of justice, including that Mr. Trump sought to have him ask the attorney general to restrict the Mueller probe in 2017. But, adhering to White House instructions, he declined to answer questions on matters not included in the Mueller report, incensing Democrats on the panel as he did so.

Less than three hours into the hearing, a visibly frustrated House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D., N.Y.) told the room: “Article III of the Nixon impeachment was based on this kind of obstruction of Congress by President Nixon.” The hearing was aimed at helping House Democrats determine whether to recommend articles of impeachment against Mr. Trump.

“Your behavior in this hearing room has been completely unacceptable,” Mr. Nadler told Mr. Lewandowski as he concluded the hearing. He said voting to hold Mr. Lewandowski in contempt of Congress was “certainly under consideration.”

Mr. Lewandowski’s testimony was the latest example of the challenge Democrats face in investigating the Trump administration, which has ranged from unresponsive to combative in its responses to the dozens of subpoenas and document requests the House has sent its way. Holding a hearing with a subject like Mr. Lewandowski allows Democrats to highlight the White House’s obstruction of its investigations, but also exposes the limits of the panel’s ability to obtain new information.

The hearing whiplashed between frustrated Democrats criticizing Mr. Lewandowski for refusing to answer even the most basic questions about his interactions with Mr. Trump, and sympathetic Republicans praising his leadership of the Trump campaign and asking him about his favorite football team.

On Thursday, the House Judiciary Committee approved a resolution to formalize procedures for its Trump impeachment investigation. Photo: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters

“Mr. Lewandowski, you are about like a fish being cleaned with a spoon,” Rep. Hank Johnson (D., Ga.) declared about an hour in. “It’s very hard to get an answer out of you.”

“Thank you for putting up with the harassment that you’re putting up with right now,” Rep. Ken Buck (R., Colo.) told the former campaign manager moments later.

Mr. Lewandowski’s most revealing comments came near the end of the hearing under questioning from Democratic counsel Barry Berke, during which Mr. Lewandowski broadly affirmed the accuracy of the Mueller report. “I have stated to the best of my knowledge that most of the information in the Mueller report is accurate,” he said. He also acknowledged not being truthful in media interviews about his interactions with the president regarding Mr. Sessions. “I have no obligation to be honest with the media,” he said.

Mr. Lewandowski’s performance immediately met with praise from Mr. Trump. On his flight to Mountain View, Calif., Mr. Trump wrote: “Such a beautiful Opening Statement by Corey Lewandowski!”

When the hearing broke for a brief recess, Mr. Lewandowski issued his own tweet: a plug for the website he launched to help him with a possible Senate campaign in New Hampshire.

“You are not on the campaign trail yet,” Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D., N.Y.) chided Mr. Lewandowski when the hearing resumed. “This is the House Judiciary Committee—act like you know the difference.”

The hearing devolved into partisan bickering soon after it began, as ranking member Rep. Doug Collins (R., Ga.) likened the panel’s proceedings to “Let’s read the Mueller report for audiobook,” accused Mr. Nadler of breaking the rules and motioned to adjourn—a move that was swiftly rejected.

Lawmakers feuded over the purpose of the hearing and each other’s tactics. When Mr. Buck asked Mr. Lewandowski whether he believed Russian President Vladimir Putin was laughing about “useful idiots” in the Democratic Party, Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D., Texas) interrupted: “I would not engage in any behavior that could be described as idiot. Never in my life or my colleagues’ have we ever discussed behaving like idiots.”

Prodded by Rep. Matt Gaetz (R., Fla.) to speculate about Democrats’ motive for calling the hearing, a stony-faced Mr. Lewandowski replied: “I think they hate this president more than they love their country.”

Rep. Ted Lieu (D., Calif.), a former active-duty officer in the U.S. Air Force, sharply rebuked him for that assertion later in the hearing.

In his report, Mr. Mueller said he didn’t establish a conspiracy between the Trump campaign and Russia, and that he declined to make a decision on whether Mr. Trump obstructed justice, citing a Justice Department policy that a sitting president can’t be indicted. He made clear he wasn’t exonerating Mr. Trump.

According to Mr. Mueller’s report, Mr. Trump in June 2017 dictated a message for Mr. Lewandowski to deliver to then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions, directing Mr. Sessions to publicly announce that the special counsel investigation was “very unfair” to the president and that Mr. Trump had done nothing wrong. The president also wanted Mr. Sessions, who had recused himself from the special counsel investigation, to say that he would meet with Mr. Mueller and direct him to limit his probe to “investigating election meddling for future elections.”

A month later, Mr. Trump inquired about the status of his message with Mr. Lewandowski, who told him it would be delivered soon. Instead, Mr. Lewandowski asked Rick Dearborn, a former chief of staff to Mr. Sessions who at the time was serving as the White House deputy chief of staff for policy, to deliver the message to Mr. Sessions. Mr. Dearborn didn’t follow through, according to the Mueller report.

Mr. Lewandowski told the committee on Tuesday that he didn’t have misgivings about delivering the message, but that he had gone on vacation.

The House Judiciary Committee has also subpoenaed Mr. Dearborn’s testimony, as well as that of former White House staff secretary Rob Porter.

On Monday, the White House sought to restrict or halt all three men’s testimony by arguing that Congress can’t compel the president’s senior advisers to testify about their conversations. White House counsel Pat Cipollone told the House committee on Monday that a member of his office would accompany Mr. Lewandowski to the hearing.

Mr. Nadler opened Tuesday’s hearing by calling the White House’s efforts to curtail or halt testimony from Mr. Trump’s associates a “dangerous new stretch” of the law and “an absolute cover-up.”

At the witness table, Mr. Lewandowski wore a dark suit with a light blue shirt and had his fingers clasped. He was flanked by a communications adviser, Emily Miller, and his lawyer, Peter Chavkin. Also accompanying him was David Bossie, a deputy campaign manager for Mr. Trump in 2016 who has since written two books with Mr. Lewandowski.

Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com and Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com
description: Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski stonewalled House Judiciary Committee lawmakers about his conversations with President Trump for nearly six hours, after the White House sought to impose limits on his testimony.
